misconceptions.name: Implemented distance-between-points program instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that computes the Euclidean distance between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) instead of a program that reads a single numeric grade (0–100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can submit this solution for Q3; the program is acceptable even though it calculates the distance between two points rather than mapping a numeric grade to a letter.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read exactly one numeric grade (0–100) and then use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and print the correct letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) according to the specified ranges. It should not compute distances or use coordinate inputs.
symptoms: Prompts the user for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade.
Uses variables x1, y1, x2, y2, d, t instead of a grade variable.
Performs arithmetic consistent with the distance formula, not with grade ranges.
Never uses any if/else or conditional logic to map the grade to a letter.
Outputs 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of 'Letter grade: ...'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or reuse of a previous distance-formula solution without adapting it to the grade-mapping requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance-formula logic and rewrite the program to: (1) read a single numeric grade from the user, (2) use an if/else-if/else chain to check which range (90–100, 80–89, etc.) the grade falls into, and (3) print the corresponding letter grade as shown in the sample run.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and output message match a standard distance-between-points exercise and do not contain any elements of a grade calculator (no single grade input, no conditional ranges, no letter output).

evidence.note: The code reads four coordinates and computes the Euclidean distance, then prints 'The distance of the two points is ...', which does not match the required grade calculator behavior.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirement
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points (x1, y1 and x2, y2) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. The entire logic, variable usage, and input/output are unrelated to grading, indicating a fundamental failure to address the prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to have either copied code from a different problem (e.g., a previous homework assignment on geometry) or completely misunderstood which problem they were supposed to solve, implementing distance calculation instead of grade calculation.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single integer or double representing a numerical grade (0-100) and use conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code asks for four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade.
Code performs coordinate subtraction, squaring, summing, and square root (distance formula).
Code prints 'The distance of the two points is' instead of 'Letter grade:'.
No conditional logic (if/else) for grading is present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to read, comprehend, or retain the instructions for the assigned problem (Q3. Grade Calculator).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the problem statement for Q3. Delete all code related to coordinate geometry and start fresh by focusing only on reading a single grade and using if-else statements to map that grade to a letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code implements the distance formula exactly, while the problem asks for a grade calculator. This is a 100% mismatch of scope and implementation.

evidence.note: The class name suggests the student is working on a geometric problem, not the requested grade calculator.
Variables and input prompts are for coordinate geometry (distance), not grade calculation.
This arithmetic implements the distance formula: sqrt((x2-x1)^2 + (y2-y1)^2). No grading logic is present.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the required grade calculator problem. This indicates either a copy-paste error, task misunderstanding, or failure to read requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem involving 2D coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2), not a grade conversion problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A-F) based on specified ranges using conditional logic.
symptoms: Code asks for four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one (grade)
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of checking grade ranges
Output is a numeric distance value instead of a letter grade
No conditional logic (if/else) for grade range checking
Class name is 'Q3DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of relating to grades
misconceptions.root_cause: Student likely submitted code from a different problem (possibly copied from a previous assignment or another source) without verifying it matches the current requirements. Failure to read problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the Q3 problem statement. Implement a new solution using if/else if/else statements to check which range the grade falls into (90-100=A, 80-89=B, 70-79=C, 60-69=D, <60=F). Read a single grade value, not four coordinate values.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Perfect confidence because the entire code solves a different problem. The distance formula code (using sqrt and coordinate math) is incompatible with any grade calculator solution. This is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Student declares variables for coordinate points and reads four values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of reading a single grade value
Student implements Euclidean distance formula (sqrt((x2-x1)^2 + (y2-y1)^2)) instead of conditional logic for grade ranges

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + d);
evidence.note: Student outputs a numeric distance value instead of a letter grade. No conditional logic present to map ranges to letter grades.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that computes the Euclidean distance between two points rather than a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0–100) and outputs a corresponding letter grade using conditional logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read one numeric grade value between 0 and 100 and then use if/else-if/else conditionals to decide whether it is an A, B, C, D, or F, and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1 and y1, x2 and y2 instead of a single grade.
Program performs arithmetic consistent with a distance formula (differences, squares, square root) instead of conditional checks on a grade range.
Program outputs a sentence about the distance between two points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have either copied or reused code for a different exercise (distance between points) and did not implement the required grade-calculation logic at all.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design the program starting from the required input and output. Replace the coordinate inputs with a single numeric grade input (e.g., int or double), then use an if/else-if chain to check ranges 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, and below 60, printing the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (input prompts, variables, computations, and output) is aligned with the distance-between-points problem and none of it relates to reading a numeric grade or determining a letter grade.

evidence.note: All logic is for computing distance between two points: reading four coordinate values, applying the distance formula, and printing the distance, with no grade input or letter-grade mapping.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address required problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates the distance between two points instead of the program required by the prompt (a Grade Calculator). The submitted code addresses a different assignment entirely.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have confused the requirements for Q3 and submitted code for a different, likely previous, exercise (Distance Between Points).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must correctly implement the logic for the Grade Calculator problem described in the prompt (reading a single grade and mapping it to a letter grade A-F using conditionals).
symptoms: Code calculates distance using Math.sqrt()
Code prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
Missing all required conditional logic (if/else if/else) for grade classification
misconceptions.root_cause: Mismanagement of files or confusion about the assignment requirements, leading to submission of irrelevant code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem description for Q3 carefully and write the program specifically designed to calculate and output a letter grade based on numeric input (0-100).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is demonstrably for a different problem (distance calculation) than the one assigned (grade calculator).

evidence.note: The class name specifically refers to 'DistanceBetweenPoints', not a grade calculator.
Variables and input prompts are for coordinate pairs, not a single numeric grade.
This code implements the Pythagorean theorem to calculate distance, a task irrelevant to grade calculation.

misconceptions.name: Submitted wrong assignment/problem
misconceptions.description: Student submitted a complete solution to a different problem (distance between two points) rather than the grade classifier problem that was assigned. This indicates either misreading the problem statement or submitting code from a different assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a coordinate distance calculation problem, not a grade classification problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a single grade value (0-100) and using conditional logic to output the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F based on specified ranges).
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate values instead of one grade
Code implements distance formula instead of grade range comparisons
Output is a decimal distance instead of a letter grade
No if-else statements for grade range checking
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either misread the problem statement or submitted the wrong code (likely from a different assignment about distance calculations).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the Q3 problem statement. Delete this code and start over with: (1) Read one numeric grade, (2) Use if-else to check ranges (≥90, ≥80, ≥70, ≥60, else), (3) Output the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extreme confidence because the submitted code is demonstrably for a completely different problem. The class is named 'Q3DistanceBetweenPoints', implements the distance formula, and reads coordinates—none of which apply to a grade calculator.

evidence.note: Reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade value. Class name and variable names reflect a distance problem, not a grade problem.
Implements the Euclidean distance formula √[(x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²], not any grade classification logic or conditional ranges.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + d);
evidence.note: Outputs a numeric distance instead of a letter grade. No if-else statement structure for grade classification.
